citations.narrative:
Upon arrival the inspectors were in the car waiting for the entrance attendant and an ostrich escape the primary drive
through enclosure when the horse drawn wagon exited the enclosure. Facility representatives then herded the ostrich
back towards the exit and held it around the neck to lead it back in the enclosure.
Escape and recapture of animal both pose a high risk of injury to the animals, employees, and the public.
Housing facilities for birds must be designed and constructed so that they are structurally sound for the species of bird
housed in them. They must be kept in good repair, protect the birds from injury, and restrict other animals from entering
that may negatively affect the welfare of the birds within. Housing facilities must employ security measures that contain all
birds securely.
Correction date: July 8th, 2024

citations.desc: Procurement of dogs, cats, and other animals; dealers.
citations.narrative:
The licensee acquired an aoudad, a camel calf, two white-tailed deer fawns, one red kangaroo, one buffalo, three water
buffalo, two yak, four Watusi, one red kangaroo, two ostrich, four rhea and four emus from persons that do not hold a
current USDA license.
All licensees must acquire wild and exotic animals used for exhibition from a licensed facility. A license is required to
ensure all parties are in compliance with the animal welfare act.
No exhibitor shall knowingly obtain any dog, cat, or other animal from any person who is required to be licensed but who
does not hold a current, valid, and unsuspended license.
Correction Date: July 8th, 2024

There are no records of adult dogs receiving parvovirus or distemper vaccines since February of 2023. There are no
records of monthly heartworm prevention, grooming, nail checks, or skin/ear checks being preformed since December of
2023. The program of veterinary care requires annual vaccination for parvovirus and distemper and monthly heartworm
prevention. Vaccination, deworming, heartworm preventative and routine health monitoring is important in protection from
contagious diseases and illness.
The written program of veterinary care must address the requirements for adequate veterinary care for every dealer and
exhibitor in § 2.40 of this subchapter and every research facility in § 2.33 of this subchapter, and must also include:
Vaccinations for contagious and/or deadly diseases of dogs (including rabies, parvovirus and distemper) and sampling
and treatment of parasites and other pests (including fleas, worms, coccidia, giardia, and heartworm) in accordance with a
schedule approved by the attending veterinarian and preventative care and treatment to ensure healthy and unmatted
hair coats, properly trimmed nails, and clean and healthy eyes, ears, skin, and teeth.
Correction Date: July 8th, 2024

The enclosure with two fox that is closest to the exit of the drive-through had two areas of the dig barrier in the enclosure
where the ground had been dug out under the dig barrier. This left exposed dig barrier that the foxes could potentially
become entrapped in and cause injury.
The enclosure with two fox that is in the shaded area to the north of the park entrance had one area of the dig barrier of
the enclosure where the ground had been dug out through the dig barrier of the enclosure. This left exposed dig barrier
that the foxes could potentially become entrapped in and cause injury.
There is a raised diesel tank in the enclosure that the highland bull was enclosed in. The hose for the tank was in easy
reach for cattle. Chewing on the hose of a filled diesel tank could cause illness of injury to a animal.
The facility must be constructed of such material and of such strength as appropriate for the animals involved. The indoor
and outdoor housing facilities shall be structurally sound and shall be maintained in good repair to protect the animals
from injury and to contain the animals.

The food receptacle for two foxes in the most westerly enclosure has an accumulation of cobwebs and spiders inside the
self-feeder.
Food receptacles must be kept clean to prevent contamination and deterioration of the food fed to the fox. Food that is
contaminated or deteriorated in nutritive value may lead to weight loss from the animals not eating the food or health
issues.
Food receptacles shall be kept clean and sanitary at all times. If self-feeders are used, adequate measures shall be taken
to prevent molding, contamination, and deterioration or caking of food.
Correction Date: July 8th, 2024
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative.
Additional Inspectors:
CARRIE BONGARD, ANIMAL CARE INSPECTOR n

narrative:
3.150(a) 
   
Facilities, general. 
Upon arrival the inspectors were in the car waiting for the entrance attendant and an ostrich escape the primary drive 
through enclosure when the horse drawn wagon exited the enclosure. Facility representatives then herded the ostrich 
back towards the exit and held it around the neck to lead it back in the enclosure. 
Escape and recapture of animal both pose a high risk of injury to the animals, employees, and the public.  
Housing facilities for birds must be designed and constructed so that they are structurally sound for the species of bird 
housed in them. They must be kept in good repair, protect the birds from injury, and restrict other animals from entering 
that may negatively affect the welfare of the birds within. Housing facilities must employ security measures that contain all 
birds securely. 
Correction date: July 8th, 2024 
2.132(d)  Critical
   
Procurement of dogs, cats, and other animals; dealers. 
The licensee acquired an aoudad, a camel calf, two white-tailed deer fawns, one red kangaroo, one buffalo, three water 
buffalo, two yak, four Watusi, one red kangaroo, two ostrich, four rhea and four emus from persons that do not hold a 
current USDA license. 
All licensees must acquire wild and exotic animals used for exhibition from a licensed facility. A license is required to 
ensure all parties are in compliance with the animal welfare act. 
No exhibitor shall knowingly obtain any dog, cat, or other animal from any person who is required to be licensed but who 
does not hold a current, valid, and unsuspended license. 
Correction Date: July 8th, 2024 
3.13(a) 
   
Veterinary care for dogs. 
There are no records of adult dogs receiving parvovirus or distemper vaccines since February of 2023. There are no 
records of monthly heartworm prevention, grooming, nail checks, or skin/ear checks being preformed since December of 
2023. The program of veterinary care requires annual vaccination for parvovirus and distemper and monthly heartworm 
prevention. Vaccination, deworming, heartworm preventative and routine health monitoring is important in protection from 
contagious diseases and illness.

The written program of veterinary care must address the requirements for adequate veterinary care for every dealer and 
exhibitor in § 2.40 of this subchapter and every research facility in § 2.33 of this subchapter, and must also include: 
Vaccinations for contagious and/or deadly diseases of dogs (including rabies, parvovirus and distemper) and sampling 
and treatment of parasites and other pests (including fleas, worms, coccidia, giardia, and heartworm) in accordance with a 
schedule approved by the attending veterinarian and preventative care and treatment to ensure healthy and unmatted 
hair coats, properly trimmed nails, and clean and healthy eyes, ears, skin, and teeth. 
Correction Date: July 8th, 2024 
3.125(a)  Repeat
   
Facilities, general. 
The enclosure with two fox that is closest to the exit of the drive-through had two areas of the dig barrier in the enclosure 
where the ground had been dug out under the dig barrier. This left exposed dig barrier that the foxes could potentially 
become entrapped in and cause injury. 
The enclosure with two fox that is in the shaded area to the north of the park entrance had one area of the dig barrier of 
the enclosure where the ground had been dug out through the dig barrier of the enclosure. This left exposed dig barrier 
that the foxes could potentially become entrapped in and cause injury. 
There is a raised diesel tank in the enclosure that the highland bull was enclosed in. The hose for the tank was in easy 
reach for cattle. Chewing on the hose of a filled diesel tank could cause illness of injury to a animal. 
The facility must be constructed of such material and of such strength as appropriate for the animals involved. The indoor 
and outdoor housing facilities shall be structurally sound and shall be maintained in good repair to protect the animals 
from injury and to contain the animals. 
3.129(b) 
   
Feeding. 
The food receptacle for two foxes in the most westerly enclosure has an accumulation of cobwebs and spiders inside the 
self-feeder. 
Food receptacles must be kept clean to prevent contamination and deterioration of the food fed to the fox. Food that is 
contaminated or deteriorated in nutritive value may lead to weight loss from the animals not eating the food or health 
issues. 
Food receptacles shall be kept clean and sanitary at all times. If self-feeders are used, adequate measures shall be taken 
to prevent molding, contamination, and deterioration or caking of food. 
Correction Date: July 8th, 2024 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative. 
 
Additional Inspectors: 
CARRIE BONGARD, ANIMAL CARE INSPECTOR n
